Authors:
Christina Zübert, Anna-Marie Ilic, Bojan Duduk, Michael
Kube
Title:
Genome Reduction of Phytoplasmas Exclude the Ribosomal Rescue
System
Keywords:
smpB, ssrA, tmRNA ribosome rescue system,
trans-translation
Abstract:
Although the ribosomal rescue system is part of the
translation system, it has been lost in some species of the Mollicutes
class due to genome instability and reduction processes. The genomes
from the provisional taxon ‘Candidatus Phytoplasma’ also underly these
processes, which even include the loss several central pathways. These
obligatory biotrophic bacteria form one clade of the Acholeplasmataceae,
while the second genus, Acholeplasma, comprises species harbouring a
comparatively broad genetic repertoire that is necessary for a
saprophytic lifestyle. In contrast to many core genes of
Acholeplasmataceae, the ribosomal rescue system has not yet been
examined in detail. Therefore, complete genomes from the family were
re-examined with respect for ssrA encoding the tmRNA and its associated
binding-protein SmpB. The analysis of the key genes of the
trans-translation system reveals particular proteolysis tag peptides,
conserved coding and associated gene context in addition to the
successful application of SmpB in phylogenetic analysis. The results
highlight the importance of the ribosomal rescue system for phytoplasmas
even under conditions of rapid genome evolution.
